awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Controlled Polycondensation Techniques as a Route to Novel Semiconducting Polymer Architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, is funding Professor Kevin Noonan of Carnegie Mellon University to develop new methods for the synthesis of organic conducting polymers.  Polymers are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life, and the research team is developing new electronic materials that are organic, meaning they are made from carbon-based molecules rather than the more commonly used inorganic materials, such as those based on silicon. Electrically conducting carbon-based (organic) molecules hold enormous promise for realizing highly efficient, affordable, and broadly available electronic and optical devices.  The precision synthesis being developed requires advances in catalyst design and a fundamental insight into how the different chemical steps of the polymer chain growth occur. This work is expected to have broader scientific impact on the science and technology of organic electronics, and will also provide an interdisciplinary research experience for both undergraduate and graduate students.  The educational activities being pursued include the integration of metal-based catalysis into required undergraduate laboratories.  Videos of the lab development are being made available online to aid in adoption at other universities. 

In this project, Professor Noonan is developing new methods for the controlled polymerization of donor-acceptor building blocks. The incorporation of electron-accepting aromatic units into polymer materials has led to great improvements in organic solar cell devices, but variability in performance is often observed with these systems due to differences in polymer batches. The aim of this research is to utilize controlled polycondensation methods to polymerize highly functional aromatic building blocks. Precision synthesis incorporating these units into polymers will require advances in metal-ligand design, an understanding of how metals interact with the growing polymer chain and, insight into how different functional groups (i.e., ketones, esters, amides) can alter the chain-growth reaction.  A library of monomers is being developed and explored with efforts towards enhanced mechanistic understanding of catalyst-transfer polycondensation and rational design of new acceptor systems amenable to this controlled polymerization approach.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program, the Noonan laboratory has developed new synthetic techniques to build conjugated polymers. A portion of the electrons in conjugated polymers reside in pi-bonds, which enables them to flow freely under certain conditions such that the material can behave as a metal or semiconductor. Precise methods for their synthesis are very important, as the polymers are very sensitive to impurities and imperfections. As part of this work, the Noonan lab has discovered how to use earth abundant nickel catalysts to construct these conjugated polymers, particularly from monomers decorated with sacrificial boron groups. The boron component is key to "activate" the monomer to be incorporated into long polymer chains. To that end, the Noonan laboratory has also developed a new synthetic strategy to attach sacrificial boron groups to aromatic molecules. One challenge in the synthesis of these polymers is that multi-step sequences are typically required, where the sacrificial boron group is attached to the monomer, the monomer is isolated, and then this compound is converted into polymer. The monomer purification ultimately adds time, expense and requires additional raw resources (e.g., solvents). To combat this challenge, the Noonan lab recently developed a strategy to carry out attachment of the boron group and polymerization in one-pot, making the overall polymerization process more practical and efficient.

The synthetic techniques developed in the Noonan laboratory were used to make a variety of conjugated polymers (shown in Figure 1). The polymerization of different monomers has revealed how choice of catalyst (nickel and palladium) impacts the quality of the final polymer. Altogether, the design of new well-defined polymers has helped the Noonan lab understand which metal catalysts are best suited for different polymers. One particularly interesting material synthesized as part of this work was derived from furan, an aromatic molecule which can be obtained directly from sugars. Polyfurans are a unique family of "green" organic electronic materials derived from biomass, with high promise for sustainable energy applications. 

Finally, the Noonan laboratory has developed several undergraduate laboratory experiments on catalysis, which have been incorporated into the lab classes at Carnegie Mellon. These experiments focus on the broad utility of organometallic compounds in the construction and manipulation of organic molecules and polymers. It is one of the first experiences Carnegie Mellon undergraduates have in synthesizing catalysts for organic transformations. These experimental procedures have also been made freely available on the Noonan laboratory website for other interested parties. Graduate and undergraduate students who worked on these projects were trained extensively and gained valuable experience in the design, synthesis and characterization of organic molecules and polymers.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2021
Modified by: Kevin Noonan

Image
  • Catalyst design for preparation of various conjugated polymers.
    Kevin Noonan
